content.description: Steep shallow pockets and crimps. Make a 20' traverse out left (drop down low after clipping the second bolt), then crank through a techy headwall of crimps, pockets, and a few slopers. Bolts 2-4 should be clipped with slings.
content.location: If it's low tide, it's best to belay down in the pit, otherwise, just tie in long to the belay bolt and belay on the edge.

content.description: Wild pocket pulling directly over the crashing waves. Have your belayer sling the big boulder and belay down low on the ramp. Step left over the abyss and pull an incredible V4 sequence left of the second bolt, then up six more bolts of steep pockets . The bolts are close and the route is steep so falls are extra clean. It felt very reminiscent to Great White except that Sprinkling Pockets is a bit shorter and has smaller holds. Absolutely incredible climbing

Fantastic pocket steep pulling. Clip the fifth bolt of Sprinkling Pockets, then fork left onto the overhanging arete that is the right side of the overhanging runnel. Finish with the last bolt of Swallow The Sea. Freakin classic.
content.location: Fork left from the fifth bolt of Swallow the Sea.

climbs.name: Porifera
climbs.fa: FA:  Tim Whilhelmi '91  FFA:  Paul Humphrey "96

content.description: Steep, well featured rock on the right hand side of South Rock.  Solid rock.

climbs.name: Osteoporosis
climbs.fa: FA Matthias, Rich, Petch, FFA: Eric Chemello

content.description:
Second route from the right on the south face of south rock. The route follows an obvious spine left of Porifera. This route was originally called Jug Haul Left before it was bolted. There are some sandy holds, but most holds are very solid.

The bolts are in decent-ish shape and are well positioned, but you'll still want a soft catch. Stick clip is needed for the opening moves.
